newsitem.title: USA: Polyester may eclipse global cotton use - economist.
newsitem.headline: Polyester may eclipse global cotton use - economist.

text.p: Led by explosive growth in Asia, a preference for polyester and other synthetic fibers is causing shrinkage in world cotton consumption.

Mark Lange, an economist with the National Cotton Council, said synthetic fiber consumption in Asia accounted for 89 percent of the 36.3 million bale increase in world synthetic fiber use, between 1984 and 1996.

"Asian consumer markets are widely expected to be the fastest growing markets for the next seven to ten years given current forecasts of GDP growth rates," Lange said. "Unfortunately, the Asian markets have seen shifts in consumption from cotton to man-made fiber."
He cited increases in synthetic fiber use in Pakistan, China, and Bangladesh, where cotton consumption has declined.
Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong have also consumed more synthetic fiber in the last five years, while cotton consumption remained fairly static, Lange said.

He blamed the trend on greater production capacity in the Far East, which grew to 52 percent of the world synthetic fiber production in 1995, from 43 percent in 1990. Projections for the year 2000 put output in the Far East at 60.8 percent.
"If these expansion plans are realized, the Far East will have greater synthetic capacity in the year 2000 than the world capacity was in 1990," Lange said.

Between 1990 and 1995, polyester use grew 6.8 percent a year while cotton use barely budged. Projections for the next five years indicate polyester use will grow by around seven percent, and cotton at 1.3 percent annually.
The breakup of the former Soviet Union, a world economic recession from 1991 to 1993, and high fiber prices in 1995 also stymied world retail cotton purchases, Lange said.

While conceding that the numbers do not bode well for cotton producers, Lange said a key to recouping world fiber share is to lower the production costs. In particular, new technologies could lower costs 8.00 to 10.00 cents a lb, Lange said.

"If we trim eight to 10 cents out of our production, processing and distribution costs over the next five to 10 years, the odds are good that we will maintain a position of leadership in world cotton production."
